citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) was not available for inspection. In order to comply with this section of the
Animal Welfare Act (AWA) a written PVC must always be in place and available for inspection. Under formal
arrangements, as directed by the AWA, the establishment must have an updated PVC by the current Attending
Veterinarian (AV). To ensure adequate veterinary medical care to regulated animals, a complete written PVC must be
readily available for inspection. Also, the contracted AV must schedule and regularly visit the establishment's premises.
Correct by March 22, 2023

There were no inventory, acquisition, or disposition records available during the inspection. The licensee advised that did
not know that they needed them.
The lack of records during inspections does not allow for proper traceability of the regulated animals by inspectors.
Complete records are needed for proper management of the regulated animals at a facility and those being acquired/held
and sold.
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make,
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning animals other
than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control.
Correct by March 22, 2023

A contingency plan was not available at time of inspection. Contingency plans help prepare facilities on how to provide
humane handling of animals during emergent events. Correct by developing a complete contingency plan tailored to the
facility and regulated animals.
Correct by 22 March 2023.

Two rabbit enclosures are used to house four of the rabbits. The largest enclosure, housing three female rabbits in a
hutch, had an accumulation of feces on the floor. The enclosure housing the single male had an accumulation of rabbit
and chicken feces on the floor of both levels of the enclosure. Due to these severe accumulations of dried feces, it was
evident that the enclosures have not been cleaned on a periodic basis.
Primary enclosures shall be kept reasonably free of excreta by periodic cleaning for the health, comfort and well-being of
the rabbits housed therein.
Correct by March 9, 2023

There is a horse stall enclosure that houses 1 domestic rabbit and 1 chicken. Housing rabbits with other species may
result in injury to the rabbits. Rabbits must not be housed in the same primary enclosure with any other species for their
health and safety.
Correct by March 9, 2023

The water containers for the cattle, sheep and goats contained an excess amount green filamentous, and sludge-like
material on the interior surfaces of the receptacles. Contaminated water can lead to disease and adverse effects for the
animals. Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitary to provide potable water to all animals.
Correct by 3/9/2023

There were an excessive number of small, black, flying insects in a pig stall and around the single male rabbit enclosure.
The insects congregated in wet bedding and food. There were no active pest control measures in place at the time of
inspection. Insects can carry disease and cause injury and irritation. A safe and effective program for the control of insects
and other pests must be established and maintained.
Correct by 3/22/23
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
End Section
